titleStmt.title: KENDAL, Kirkby-Kendal, or Kirkby-in-Kendal (9th edition, volume 14, page 34)

listBibl.head: Alternate image sources for this edition:
listBibl.desc: Alternate images of the same print editions were substituted when the primary source had unusable images for those pages.
listBibl.bibl: Hathi Trust, from print source at the University of Michigan: vol. 14, pp. 34-35; vol. 15, pp. 170-171.

correction.p: This electronic text file was created by optical character recognition (OCR). OCR errors have not been corrected.
Illegible text in the original is indicated using unclear or gap, as appropriate. If corrected, the reference source is indicated with supplied.

normalization.p: Original spelling is preserved. When noticed, obvious misspellings are combined with the correct spelling as choice in the TEI. Ligatures are reproduced as multiple letters. Original footnote and marginal note sigla are replaced with sequential numbers for each entry.

punctuation.p: Extra space around punctuation marks is removed.

quotation.p: Quotation marks are retained as content in the text. Redundant open quotation marks at the start of lines inside block quotes are silently removed.

segmentation.p: The div type="entry" element divides the text into individual entries.
The div type="section" and div type="subsection" elements are reserved for future entry subsections.

list.item: Encoding uses the recommendations for Level 3 of the TEI in Libraries Guidelines.
Individual entries and page-breaks are encoded, but column breaks are omitted.
Running headers and side descriptions are not included.
Some font formatting is preserved: italic, small caps, strike-through, subscript, superscript, underline. The following formatting is ignored: bold, font size, typeface.

projectDesc.p: All text was encoded for the Nineteenth-Century Knowledge Project to provide a machine-readable edition of the Encyclopedia Britannica to analyze.
Subject-level metadata was added to each entry using the HIVE automated vocabulary server created by the Metadata Research Center at Drexel University (https://hive2.cci.drexel.edu).

samplingDecl.p: The first release is a reproduction of text matter for all entries. It does not include images, tables, formulae, front- or back-matter. It omits volume 1, which consists of "Dissertations" rather than entries.

prefixDef.p: URIs with the prefix fast: point to terms in the OCLC FAST (Faceted Application of Subject Terminology) subject heading schema derived from the Library of Congress Subject Headings (LCSH).
URIs with the prefix lcsh1910: point to subject terms in the volume Subject Headings Used in the Dictionary Catalogues of the Library of Congress, 7 vols., Library of Congress, 1910.
URIs with the prefix ht: point to page images in the Hathi Trust.
URIs with the prefix ia: point to page images in the Internet Archive.
URIs with the prefix nls: point to page images in the National Library of Scotland.

div.p: KENDAL, Kirkby-Kendal, or Kirkby-in-Kendal, a market-town and parliamentary and municipal borough of Westmoreland, is picturesquely situated in a pleasant valley on the east bank of the Kent or Ken, 44 miles south of Carlisle (50 by rail), and 241 miles from London. The town, which is the largest and most populous in the county, is very irregularly built, but the white-walled houses with their blue-slated roofs, and the numerous trees, give it a very attractive appearance. There are four leading streets, two of which together form a spacious thoroughfare a mile in length. The church of the Holy Trinity, whose oldest part dates from about 1200, is a Gothic edifice with five aisles and α square tower 72 feet high. Kendal contains numerous other churches, a town-hall, a mechanics’ institution, a literary and scientific institution, a museum, and a chamber of commerce. Its charities include a hospital (founded 1870), an old maids' hospital, α girls’ orphanage, almshouses, <fcc. The free grammar school is well endowed; and there are also in the town a well-endowed blue-coat school and hospital, a large national school, a school of science and art, and several Sunday schools, among which is the Greencoat Sunday school, founded in 1813. On an eminence to the east of the town are the ruins of Kendal Castle, attributed to the first barons of Kendal. It was the birthplace of Catherine Parr, Henry VIII.’s last queen. On the Castle-law-hill, an obelisk was raised in 1788 in memory of the revolution of 1688. The woollen manufactures of Kendal have been noted since the 14th century, when Edward III. established a colony of Flemish weavers in the town; and, although the coarse cloth known to Shakespeare as “Kendal green” is no longer made, its place is more than supplied by active manufactures of tweeds, linsey-wolsey, railway rugs, horse clothing, knitted woollen caps and jackets, worsted and woollen yarns, and similar goods. Other manufactures of Kendal are machine-made boots and shoes, cards for wool and cotton, agricultural and other machinery, paper, and, in the neighbourhood, gunpowder. There are also important marble-works. There is a large weekly market for grain, and annual horse and cattle fairs. The population in 1881 was 13,696, an increase of only 250 from 1871.

Kendal was the head of a barony given by William the Conqueror to Ivo de Talbois. It has given the title of earl to various royal and other personages of English history. The town received its charter from Queen Elizabeth in 1575. A second, granted by Charles I., and confirmed by Charles II., was superseded by the Municipal Act of 1835, according to which the town is governed by six aidermen and eighteen councillors, who select a mayor from among themselves. Quarter sessions are held alternately at Appleby and Kendal. The Reform Act of 1832 assigned one member of parliament to Kendal.
